Interestingly, the word unsavory — which is clearly the opposite of savory — is almost never used to describe food. If some a dish doesn't taste good, it, well, isn't good-tasting. If something is unsavory, then it's probably a person or situation that seems morally questionable. So, save savory for delicious food and save unsavory for things, people and ideas deserving of the adjective.

teem.colored_long: Don't confuse [31mteem[0m with [31mteam[0m. The two words may sound the same, but they have different meanings. Use the noun [31mteam[0m when describing a group of people with a common goal, and turn to the verb [31mteem[0m for those times when you need to say that something is overflowing or crowded. [31mTeem[0m is almost always used with the preposition [31mwith[0m, as when the busy streets teem with activity.

vernal.colored_long: The word [31mvernal[0m entered English in the sixteenth century, tracing all the way back to the Latin word [31mver[0m, meaning spring. Use the adjective [31mvernal[0m to describe something that occurs in springtime or is related to springtime. You might be familiar with the vernal equinox, which indicates the beginning of spring in the Northern Hemisphere. The word [31mvernal[0m can also be used more broadly to describe something youthful or fresh — springlike.
vernal.colored_short: If you enjoy the [31mvernal[0m lushness of the landscape, that’s a kind of fancy way to say you like the way nature looks in the springtime.
